columns.name: subscriber_name
columns.description: The name of your Amazon Security Lake subscriber account.

columns.name: subscription_id
columns.description: The subscription ID of the Amazon Security Lake subscriber account.

columns.name: created_at
columns.description: The date and time when the subscription was created.

columns.name: subscription_status
columns.description: Subscription status of the Amazon Security Lake subscriber account.

columns.name: updated_at
columns.description: The date and time when the subscription was updated.

columns.name: external_id
columns.description: The external ID of the subscriber.

columns.name: role_arn
columns.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) specifying the role of the subscriber.

columns.name: s3_bucket_arn
columns.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the Amazon S3 bucket.

columns.name: sns_arn
columns.description: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the Amazon Simple Notification Service.

columns.name: subscriber_description
columns.description: The subscriber descriptions for a subscriber account.

columns.name: subscription_endpoint
columns.description: The subscription endpoint to which exception messages are posted.

columns.name: subscription_protocol
columns.description: The subscription protocol to which exception messages are posted.

columns.name: access_types
columns.description: You can choose to notify subscribers of new objects with an Amazon Simple Queue Service (Amazon SQS) queue or through messaging to an HTTPS endpoint provided by the subscriber. Subscribers can consume data by directly querying Lake Formation tables in your S3 bucket via services like Amazon Athena. This subscription type is defined as LAKEFORMATION.

columns.name: source_types
columns.description: Amazon Security Lake supports logs and events collection for the natively-supported Amazon Web Services services.
